techniques.name: sauté
techniques.description: Cooking food quickly in a small amount of fat over relatively high heat.
tips: Use a pan large enough to hold food in a single layer
Pat ingredients dry to promote browning
Don't overcrowd the pan or food will steam instead of sauté
Keep food moving with a spatula or by tossing

techniques.name: roast
techniques.description: Cooking food with dry heat in an oven, often with fat.
tips: Preheat oven thoroughly before adding food
Use a similar size for cut ingredients to ensure even cooking
Allow meats to rest before carving
For crispy exteriors, avoid overcrowding the pan

techniques.name: boil
techniques.description: Cooking food in water or liquid that has reached 212°F (100°C) at sea level.
tips: Salt water for pasta and vegetables to enhance flavor
Start with cold water for even cooking of starches and legumes
Use plenty of water to prevent sticking
Boil delicate vegetables briefly to retain nutrients

techniques.name: simmer
techniques.description: Cooking food gently in liquid just below boiling point, with small bubbles rising to the surface.
tips: Cover pot to retain heat and moisture
Adjust heat as needed to maintain gentle bubbling
For stocks and stews, skim foam from the surface periodically
Check liquid levels to prevent drying out

techniques.name: steam
techniques.description: Cooking food using the vapor from boiling water without immersing in the water itself.
tips: Ensure water doesn't touch the food
Keep lid on to trap steam
Check water level to prevent burning pot
Arrange food in single layer for even cooking

techniques.name: grill
techniques.description: Cooking food with direct heat from below, often over flames or hot coals
tips: Preheat grill thoroughly before adding food
Use a similar size for cut ingredients to ensure even cooking
Turn food occasionally to cook evenly
Use a meat thermometer to check doneness
